summary: the aim of this research was to evaluate long-term pulmonary sequelae on paired inspiration-expiration thin-section computed tomography (CT) scans 3 years after influenza A (H1N1) virus-associated pneumonia. the patients underwent thin-section CT 3 years after recovery. patients who need more steroid therapy, need more mechanical ventilation therapy, had higher laboratory tests results (maximum levels of AST, LDH, and CK) and higher peak opacification on chest radiographs are more likely to develop lung fibrosis. thin-section computed tomographic scanning is more sensitive than chest radiography and provides more detailed radiological features. the purpose of this study was to evaluate the radiological changes on paired inspiration-expiration thin-section chest CT scans in patients 3 years after H1N1 virus-associated pneumonia during the postdischarge period. ninety patients who received an initial diagnosis of H1N1 virus-associated pneumonia were included in the study. four patients had coronary heart disease, two patients had cirrhosis, and two patients had diabetes. follow-up pulmonary function testing was performed in all 24 patients. patients complained of exertional dyspnea and/or reduced exercise tolerance. thin-section CT findings were described on the basis of the recommendations of the nomenclature committee of the Fleischner Society. the observers assessed the presence of ground-glass opacity, consolidation, reticulation (interlobular septal thickening and intralobular lines), parenchymal bands, honeycombing, traction bronchiectasis, air trapping, and architectural distortion. the presence of architectural distortion, traction bronchiectasis, or honeycombing each lung was divided into three zones: upper, middle, and lower. each of the three zones spanned one-third of the craniocaudal distance of the lung on a frontal radiograph. nasopharyngeal or nasopharyngeal specimens from all patients were evaluated by real-time polymerase chain reaction at the center for disease control and prevention, china. eight patients died during hospitalization; the remaining 82 patients were discharged after clinical improvement. four patients had coronary heart disease, two had cirrhosis, and two had diabetes. follow-up pulmonary function testing was performed in all 24 patients. patients complained of exertional dyspnea and/or reduced exercise tolerance at clinical follow-up. observers assessed presence of ground-glass opacity, consolidation, reticulation (interlobular septal thickening and intralobular lines), parenchymal bands, honeycombing, traction bronchiectasis, air trapping. the presence of architectural distortion, traction bronchiectasis, or honeycombing was considered as evidence of fibrosis. each lung was divided into three zones: upper, middle, and lower. each of the three zones spanned one-third of the craniocaudal distance of the lung. the average percentage of each zone was 100%. twenty of the 24 patients underwent 31 chest CT scans between 1 and 3 weeks after the onset of H1N1 symptoms. nine patients had only one chest CT scan and 11 patients had two CT scans within the 3 weeks. ground-glass opacity and consolidation were noted in 100% (12/12) and 58.3% (7/12) of patients in the 1st week and in 100% (11/11) and 72.7% (8/11) of patients in the 2nd week. 41.7%) and traction bronchiectasis (2/24; 8.3%) were found. traction bronchiectasis represents irregular bronchial and bronchiolar dilatation caused by surrounding pulmonary fibrosis. air trapping is defined as parenchymal areas with less than normal increase in attenuation seen on end-expiration CT scans. it has been reported that the extent of air trapping assessed by expiratory CT significantly correlate with airflow obstruction. differences between patients with CT evidence of fibrosis and those without are most likely a reflection of the severity of influenza pneumonia. CK is also a biomarker of severity in H1N1 infection. the need for pulsed steroid therapy may reflect the magnitude of the cytokine “storm” elicited by the viral antigen. ARDS frequently is followed by fibrosis in lung. fibrosis has developed in the anterior portion of the lungs, which showed only mild involvement during the acute phase. it is difficult to compare the changes in serial thin-section CT from patients with novel swine-origin H1N1 infection between short-term and long-term follow-up.
